M.G.L. c. 208 \u00a7 28.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 208 § 28, a custody judgment may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances, and when the proposed modification serves the “best interests of the child.”

Massachusetts General Laws c. 208 \u00a7.proposition: The Plaintiff, Jessica Thompson, residing in Bristol County, Massachusetts, brings this Complaint pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 208 § 28, which authorizes the Probate and Family Court to modify existing custody judgments upon a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the welfare of the minor children.

M.G.L. c. 209 \u00a7 37.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (M.G.L. c. 208 § 28; M.G.L. c. 209 § 37; M.G.L. c. 209C § 20)

M.G.L. c. 209C \u00a7 20.proposition: (court may modify custody or support orders based on changes affecting child welfare).

M.G.L. c. 215 \u00a7 6.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper under M.G.L. c. 215 § 6 and M.G.L. c. 208 § 28, as both parents and the minor children reside within Bristol County.

M.G.L. c. 208 \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: (statutory authority for modification and determination of custody in the best interests of the child).

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The controlling standard in Massachusetts for modification of custody orders is articulated in Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006)—the party seeking modification must demonstrate that circumstances have materially changed and that modification is in the best interests of the children.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas does not articulate the general Massachusetts standard for modification of custody orders requiring a material change in circumstances and best interests of the child. Instead, it addresses initial custody determinations and, more specifically, the standard for removal of children from the Commonwealth (“real advantage” test) under G.L. c. 208, § 30. The case nowhere discusses modification standards or a material-change requirement, so citing it for that proposition is inaccurate.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815)….”}

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The controlling standard in Massachusetts for modification of custody orders is articulated in Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006)—the party seeking modification must demonstrate that circumstances have materially changed and that modification is in the best interests of the children.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, §30, and it frames the standard there as whether removal is in the children’s best interests. The opinion does not articulate or apply the general Massachusetts standard for modification of custody orders as requiring a showing of a material change in circumstances plus best interests, nor does it cite Yannas for such a two-part modification test. The only explicit ‘substantial change in circumstances’ discussion appears in a quoted ALI Principles provision, not as a holding of the court, so the case does not support the proposition as stated.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”}विद्यालयишк```

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly emphasized the necessity of fostering positive relationships between both parents and protecting children from parental disparagement:
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly endorses the value of children having frequent and continuing contact with both parents and acknowledges that children are entitled to the love, companionship, and concern of both parents. It also cites Felton v. Felton for the principle that promoting the children’s best interests may require limiting a parent’s liberties when the parents are at odds, which implicitly includes preventing behaviors (such as conflict and undermining) that harm the children’s welfare. Thus, the case supports the general proposition that Massachusetts courts emphasize fostering positive relationships with both parents and shielding children from harmful parental conflict or disparagement, even though it does not use the word “disparagement” explicitly.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The husband does argue, however, that it is most often preferred that both parents participate in the child rearing process and in the major decisions that attach thereto. We agree with the precept that ‘the law sees a value in “frequent and continuing contact” of the children with both . . . parents.’ … Children are entitled to the love, companionship and concern of both parents, and they usually are better off if the parents can agree to share in the responsibility of their rearing as well as in physical custody.”

Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555.raw_text: Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555 (1980)
Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly emphasized the necessity of fostering positive relationships between both parents and protecting children from parental disparagement:
Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on standards for modifying custody (best interests of the child, change in circumstances, and not using custody to punish parents) and on comparing the stability and adequacy of each home. It does not discuss fostering positive relationships with both parents, co-parenting, or protecting the child from parental disparagement. The case is therefore not authority for the specific proposition about encouraging positive relationships with both parents and guarding against disparagement.
Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555.relevant_excerpt: “Although it cannot be denied that Michele acted improperly in removing the child to Germany and Colorado without the consent of Raymond, ‘this conduct on her part cannot be permitted to interfere with the welfare of the child, the paramount and governing consideration.’ … ‘This is not a proceeding to discipline [Michele] for her shortcomings. It is not a proceeding to reward [Raymond] for any wrong he may have suffered. It is a proceeding solely with reference to the custody of a little [child].’”

White v. Laingor, 434 Mass. 64 (2001).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly emphasized the necessity of fostering positive relationships between both parents and protecting children from parental disparagement:
White v. Laingor, 434 Mass. 64 (2001).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on public policy governing agreements to trade reduced child support for surrender of parental rights, emphasizing the need for judicial review to ensure the child’s best interests. It does not discuss fostering positive relationships with both parents or issues of parental disparagement. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about promoting positive parent–child relationships and protecting children from disparaging a parent.
White v. Laingor, 434 Mass. 64 (2001).relevant_excerpt: “We therefore hold that an agreement between parents to reduce child support obligations in exchange for the surrender of parental rights, without a judicial finding that the proposed agreement is in the best interests of a child, violates public policy.”

Zullo v. Goguen, 423 Mass. 679 (1996).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly emphasized the necessity of fostering positive relationships between both parents and protecting children from parental disparagement:
Zullo v. Goguen, 423 Mass. 679 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns procedural issues about service and appellate review of abuse prevention orders under G.L. c. 209A and does not discuss custody, parenting relationships, or parental disparagement. There is no language emphasizing fostering positive relationships between both parents or protecting children from disparagement. Using this case to support that proposition would be inaccurate and out of context.
Zullo v. Goguen, 423 Mass. 679 (1996).relevant_excerpt: We turn to our second concern, which relates to the proper procedure for seeking review of a G. L. c. 209A order. Our prior cases have recognized G. L. c. 211, § 3, as the only available route to obtain such review... However, following our reasoning in Department of Revenue v. Jarvenpaa, 404 Mass. 177 (1989), we conclude that, henceforth, review of orders pursuant to G. L. c. 209A should not be initiated by petition under G. L. c. 211, § 3, but rather by the filing of an appeal in the Appeals Court.

Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly emphasized the necessity of fostering positive relationships between both parents and protecting children from parental disparagement:
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).support_reasoning: The case is primarily about religious instruction and visitation, but the court expressly recognizes the legal policy favoring a child’s “frequent and continuing contact” with both parents and warns against depriving a parent of connection with the child due to exaggerated fears of harm. Although it does not explicitly use the language of ‘parental disparagement,’ its reasoning is grounded in protecting the parent-child relationship with both parents and minimizing unnecessary judicial interference, which aligns with the general proposition about fostering positive relationships with both parents.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “The law, however, tolerates and even encourages up to a point the child’s exposure to the religious influences of both parents although they are divided in their faiths. This, we think, is because the law sees a value in ‘frequent and continuing contact’ of the child with both its parents… A warning is equally in order against depriving a parent of all connection with the child, or connection on the religious plane, out of an exaggerated fear of injury to the child.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly emphasized the necessity of fostering positive relationships between both parents and protecting children from parental disparagement:
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on interpreting the Massachusetts best‑interests standard and the statutory factors in G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), especially preservation of stable caregiving arrangements. It discusses maintaining and fostering the child’s relationships with both parents in a structural, time-allocation sense, but it does not address or emphasize duties to foster *positive* relationships with the other parent or to protect the child from parental disparagement. There is no discussion of disparagement, bad‑mouthing, or similar conduct, so the case does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “The judgment was structured to ensure that both parents, each of whom had, during the pendency of the action, exercised responsibility as Kali’s caregiver, and each of whom had established a positive parental relationship with her, would be able to preserve, foster, and strengthen those relationships. Kali is to spend school weekdays with her mother ... To the same end, the order provides that Kali is to spend most school year weekends with her father....”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly emphasized the necessity of fostering positive relationships between both parents and protecting children from parental disparagement:
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on relocation and custody-modification standards (real-advantage test, material change in circumstances, deference to the custodial parent) rather than explicitly articulating a general principle about fostering positive relationships with both parents or protecting children from parental disparagement. While the court notes the child benefits from frequent and continuing contact with each parent and from extended family, it does not frame this as a repeatedly emphasized Massachusetts doctrine about positive relationships and disparagement. Thus, it only tangentially relates to the proposition and does not clearly establish it as a legal rule.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Caleb was found to be a ‘physically and emotionally healthy’ boy whose ‘frequent, continuing and equal interaction . . . with each parent is most beneficial to him.’ ‘Both parents serve as equally important guides for this child’s continued healthy development.’ ‘The Court finds the minor child’s life is enriched by each parent’s equal participation in his upbringing.’ These findings would not support a decision denying removal.”
